nodes.text: Teacher test-score value-added (VA) measures are informative about teachers' causal long-term impacts on students' adult outcomes (college attendance, college quality, earnings, and other life outcomes)

Data linkage and sample: administrative school records (grades 3–8, 1989–2009) were linked to US tax records (1996–2011) to follow ~1.1 million students (6.8 million student-subject-year observations) into adulthood

Research designs: (A) cross-classroom comparisons conditioning on rich observables including lagged test scores; (B) quasi-experimental cohort-differencing exploiting teacher turnover within school-grade cells (leave-two-year-out VA estimates to avoid mechanical bias)

Statistical assumptions and identification: Assumption 1 (forecast unbiasedness of VA estimates), Assumption 2 (selection on observables for cross-class design), Assumption 3 (teacher turnover orthogonal to cohort shocks for quasi-experiment); use teacher-fixed effects, leave-year-out VA, and clustering by school-cohort

Result—College attendance: a one standard deviation (SD) increase in teacher VA in a single grade raises probability of college attendance at age 20 by about 0.82 percentage points (mean = 37%), estimate replicated in quasi-experimental design (~0.86 pp)

Result—College quality and years: a one SD increase in teacher VA raises earnings-based college quality at age 20 by about $299 (1.1%) and increases probability of attending a high-quality college and of spending four or more years in college

Result—Earnings and other adult outcomes: a one SD increase in teacher VA in a single grade raises annual earnings at age 28 by ~1.3–1.65% (≈$350), reduces teenage births (~0.61 pp for females), raises neighborhood SES and 401(k) participation

Evidence—Fade-out and re-emergence: teachers' impacts on contemporaneous test scores fade rapidly over subsequent years (stabilize ~25% of initial effect after 3–4 years) but impacts on adult outcomes re-emerge and grow in the twenties (earnings trajectory steeper)

Quasi-experimental validation: cohort-differencing estimates of VA effects on college attendance and college quality closely match cross-class estimates and pass placebo timing tests, supporting causal interpretation

Heterogeneity: impacts somewhat larger for females; English teacher VA yields larger long-term impacts per test-score SD than math (English gains per SD-test-score much higher), impacts roughly constant in percentage terms across parental income but larger absolute gains for high-income children

Method detail—modeling and estimation: linear reduced-form specification Y = a + kappa_g m_jt + error; kappa_g interpretable as reduced-form effect per 1 SD of teacher test-score VA; net-of-tracking impacts computed by estimating tracking coefficients and adjusting reduced-form estimates

Policy simulations: removing bottom 5% of teachers (true VA) would increase present value of students' lifetime income by ~ $407,000 per classroom (elementary); accounting for estimation noise and drift reduces gain to ~$185,000 per classroom using 3 years of VA data; deselection yields larger net gains than paying retention bonuses to high-VA teachers because most bonuses go to teachers who would stay

Limitation and caveats: VA measures capture only impacts correlated with test-score gains (kappa_g is a lower bound for earnings VA), potential for behavioral responses (teaching to test, cheating) if VA used for high stakes, drift and estimation error reduce predictive power, and some methodological assumptions (additivity across grades, impossibility to estimate teachers' earnings-VA directly) limit structural interpretation

Conclusion: teacher VA measures currently used are informative about long-term student outcomes and imply large social returns to improving teacher quality, but practical adoption requires managing measurement noise, drift, incentive effects, and incorporating complementary evaluation metrics
